div.l: Al can he pleye on giterne or Ribil
Revel and trouthe as in A low degre
They be ful wroth alday as men may se
This ioli Prentis with his maister stood
Til he was neer oute of his prentishod
Al were he stubbid bothe erly and late
And sum tyme led with Revel to Newgate
But atte laste his maister him bethouȝte
Vp on
A Proverbe þᵗat saith þe same word
Wel bet is roten appil oute of horde
Thenne þat he roten al þe remenᵃaunt
So farith it be A riotous seruaunt
It is ful lasse harm to lat him pas
Thanne he sholde al þe ʆseruauntꝭis in þe plas
Therfore his maister yaf him acquietaunce
And bad him go with sorou ⁊and myschaunce
And þus þis ioli prentis hadde his leve
Now let him riot al þe nyȝt or leve
And for þer is no theef withouten look
That helpith him to waste or to sowke
Of þat he bribe can or borow may
Anon he sellith his bed and his aray
Vnto a compiere of his owen sort
That lovith dise riot and disport
And hadde A wif þat held for contenaunce
A shoppe and swyued for hir sustenaunce
Here endith þe cokys tale and
Begynneth þe man of lawis prolog
Ovre hoost saw wel that the brighte sonne
The ark of his artificial day hath ronne
The ferthe part and half an hour and moore
And thogh he were nat depe ystert in loore
He wiste it was the eightene the day
Of April / that is messager to May
And saw wel / that the shadwe of euery tree
Was as in lengthe / the same quantitee
That was the body erect that caused it
